Docs.summary: Specifies the method the <see cref="T:System.Windows.Controls.VirtualizingStackPanel"> uses to manage virtualizing its child items.

remarks.format:
## Remarks By default, a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.VirtualizingStackPanel> creates an item container for each visible item and discards it when it is no longer needed (such as when the item is scrolled out of view). When an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl> contains a many items, the process of creating and discarding item containers can negatively affect performance. When <xref:System.Windows.Controls.VirtualizingPanel.VirtualizationMode%2A> is set to F:System.Windows.Controls.VirtualizationMode.Recycling?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True, the T:System.Windows.Controls.VirtualizingStackPanel?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True reuses item containers instead of creating a new one each time.
When T:System.Windows.Controls.VirtualizingStackPanel?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True cannot recycle item containers, it uses the standard mode of virtualization, which is to create and discard item containers for each item. The following list describes cases when the T:System.Windows.Controls.VirtualizingStackPanel?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True cannot recycle item containers:
- The T:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True contains item containers of different types. For example, a T:System.Windows.Controls.Menu?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True might have items that use both T:System.Windows.Controls.MenuItem?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True and T:System.Windows.Controls.Separator?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True objects as the item containers.
- You explicitly create the item containers for the T:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True.
